1674848606170546177.text:
Takes like this are literally true but I think miss the mark by a long way.

New knowledge is generated by conjecture and refutation. A synthetic data generation system is essentially the conjecture part. You just have to add some way to filter/score the generations.

1674854734396809216.text:
@tdietterich I'm not sure what you're really claiming. Do you believe for example that an LLM couldn't conjecture a plausible new explanation for a phenomenon that we could test?

The LLM alone wouldn't be generating new knowledge but connected to an experiment it would.

1674849116676050946.text: Building a company in the bay is still waaay easier than from the UK

1674847642587910144.text:
Can anyone explain to me why pgvector would be less accurate than qdrant?

Are they approximating nearest neighbours in significantly different ways?

I'm aware of accelerated NN search algos like KD-trees or Orchard's algorithm but nothing approximate and would love to learn!

1674669645570392065.text:
Contrary to popular opinion, I see a lot of companies finetuning LLMs.

They just tend to do it after things are working. 
Start with prompt engineering, solve a real customer need and then optimise.

1674802600850649088.text:

That said, there are high value tasks where atm only GPT-4 is powerful enough.

1671927638649102336.text:
Benchmarks for LLMs are tricky to interpret. The models differ in subtle ways. You have to interact. They have different "personalities"

Pi is finetuned to feel like a friend or a therapist but is more prone to hallucination and is more suggestible than GPT-3.5 or Claude.

1671273856542048256.text: Interesting! Anyone able to confirm if true or is this grist for the rumor mill?

1670970898290016257.text: @bill_tirrill @akashmjn @PeterDiamandis Fair enough but as I said originally,  what does that have to do with exponentials. I think the answer is very little.  It's an important topic and I think this impedes understanding.

1670888850539835416.text: @bill_tirrill @akashmjn @PeterDiamandis That is both a list of powers and a geometric progression. Subsequent terms grow by a constant factor of 10^3.  Exponential growth is growth proportional to current size. Technically this progression is growing exponentially but the tweet doesn't aid understanding.

1670732492880457728.text: @akashmjn @PeterDiamandis If you concede the first point the second obviously follows. Something that's wrong is not a helpful guide to understanding...

1670596750451650561.text: In NY for a few days. If you're build an AI first product and wan't to compare notes, share best practices or just have a chat, DMs open.

1670582916961689600.text: @akashmjn @PeterDiamandis Yes this is a geometric progression but it's only loosely connected to exponential growth.  I suspect for anyone who doesn't already understand exponentials this will just mislead. It makes me suspect OP doesn't understand either.

1661988087914741760.text: @haldaume3 You can invent comically improbable scenarios to test llms

1661796816122261504.text: @s16h_ He didn't think it was a good thing. He thinks we won't be able to keep control

1661791473992433666.text: @geoffreyhinton "I'm told if you have a good reputation that you can say one crazy thing and people will take you seriously. Well I'm about to say a second crazy thing"

1661782421967126528.text: @eshear There's still a concept of a "mode". Its the most likely point but its not necessarily representative of a typical sample.

1661782256103432192.text: @eshear Yeah, in high dims samples near the mode become pretty rare. E.g think of flipping a biased coin 100 times with p_heads=0.9. 100 heads is the mode but there's only 1 way to achieve it. Many more ways to achieve other combinations even if they're less probable.

1661781745748914200.text: @eshear Yeah I think that's pretty reasonable!

1644047490860085256.text:
Since GPT-4 has well-calibrated confidence we can use its confidence estimates to decide when to trust the model. 

If the calibration is good, then we don't need to worry about models making things up.

1644047492571361308.text: Just ask the model for its confidence and ignore low-confidence answers.

1640754083840622595.text:
@IntuitMachine @ylecun His argument is that for autoregressive models, errors accumulate. So the longer the length of the chain the more likely it is that an LLM makes a factual error.

Worse than this the probability of error multiplies so the  probability of error grows exponentially in length.

1640754316700012544.text:
@IntuitMachine @ylecun So what he's really saying is that it's very hard to make long autoregressive LLMs be factually correct.

For what its worth I don't agree and think the argument has simplified too much.

1639562153354035201.text: @phc27x @fhuszar Will have a read/watch/think and revert.

1622033232232611841.text:
The ReAct Paper is next-level prompt engineering.

If you understand how it works then you can start building LLM apps that are way more factual than chatGPT and can use external APIs and tools. Check-out the example at the end.

To understand ReAct, let's think step-by-step: https://t.co/Pdqv1F5eFu

1622393593930612736.text:
Is LLM finetuning worth it?

If you know what you're doing, finetuned models can be 30x smaller❗️without losing performance. This can unlock applications that would otherwise be too expensive or slow.

STaR is a great example of doing it right.
(DIY instructions at the end) https://t.co/OfVEkUnAzf

How can you tell if an LLM app is working well?

Trad software relies on unit tests and trad machine learning used held-out datasets. With LLMs, neither of these is enough.

There's a fantastic example in the HELM benchmark showing why (and what you might do instead): https://t.co/0QFzAn23F6

A perfectly calibrated model will get 10% of the answers correct when it has 10% confidence, 20% at 20% confidence etc.  So on the graph above, perfect calibration corresponds to a straight line.

GPT-4 is very well-calibrated! It knows what it doesn't know!

2/You can improve factual accuracy by including external knowledge or APIs in the prompt.

3/ Action-prompting is ok for simple questions but if the question requires reasoning then it tends to fail.

 "Chain of Thought" prompting lets you over come this. In your prompt you include explicit reasoning and this gets the model to do the same. This increases accuracy: https://t.co/UsApA8I4UH

1358700587274166273.text: I continue to be amazed by how little of academic ML research looks how we collect and label data, given that for almost any real application this is the biggest factor in performance.

1625628595485016066.text: I think the wider pattern of models generating their own training data is the most interesting aspect of the Toolformer paper and will likely become a common framework for continuously improving LLMs.

1625628562203213834.text:
5/ The key insight in the paper is to use the LLM to generate its own training data! It's a three-step process:

1. Generate — Use GPT-J to annotate questions with possible API
2. Filter — keep only the examples that improve prediction
3. Finetune — retrain the model https://t.co/3D8dVBDQI8

1625628580976955392.text:
All that changes between these papers is what they use to generate and filter.

STaR
Generate: chain-of-thought reasoning
Filter: Accuracy on training examples

Constitutional AI
Generate: Instruction prompts
Filter: A second LLM with a set of rules https://t.co/OwKxu1XdjJ

4/ Toolformer teaches GPT-J to use tools through finetuning.

Just prompting works fine for GPT-3 (see ReAct https://t.co/uEfYIWDQth)

1622393623332651009.text: 3/ The key-idea in STaR is to bootstrap data generation. They first generate "chain-of-thought" reasoning for a dataset of questions/answer pairs. 1622033244215726080.text: 1/ The simplest possible prompt is a "zero-shot" instruction prompt. You just ask the model to do what you want. This works *ok* but the model still has a tendency to make things up and it doesn't know about changing world events or private info. https://t.co/b3BM3mPdQM

1600933314109394945.text:
It's wild to me that when considering resources people don't consider the benefits at all.

Resource consumption in NLP (both $ and carbon) is absolutely tiny. Even if you think these models don't "understand" language, they're being used by millions of people in useful products.
